heading: # Grid system
headingText: Vuetify comes with a 12 point grid system built using <kbd>flex-box</kbd>. The grid is used to create specific layouts within an application's content.  It contains 5 types of media breakpoints that are used for targeting specific screen sizes or orientations, **xs**, **sm**, **md**, **lg** and **xl**. These resolutions are defined below in the Viewport Breakpoints table and can be modified by customizing the [Breakpoint service](/customization/breakpoints).
headerAlert1: 1.x grid system has been deprecated in favor of the 2.x grid system. Documentation for 1.x grids can be found in the [v1.5 docs](https://v15.vuetifyjs.com/framework/grid)
usageText2: In the example above, we created three equal-width columns on small, medium, large and extra large devices. The parent `v-container` to center the inner `v-col`s.
usageList: `v-container` provides the ability to center and horizontally pad your site's contents. You can also use the **fluid** prop to fully extend the container across all viewport and device sizes. Maintains previous 1.x functionality in which props are passed through as classes on `v-container` allowing for the application of helper classes (such as `ma-#`/`pa-#`/`fill-height`) to easily be applied

`v-row` is a wrapper component for `v-col`. It utilizes flex properties to control the layout and flow of its inner columns. It uses a standard gutter of **24px**. This can be reduced with the **dense** prop or removed completely with **no-gutters**. This is the 2.x replacement for `v-layout` in 1.x.
`v-col` is a content holder that must be a direct child of `v-row`. This is the 2.x replacement for `v-flex` in 1.x.
usageText3: Ensure that you understand the limitations and [bugs around flexbox](https://github.com/philipwalton/flexbugs), such as the inability to [utilize certain HTML elements as flex containers](https://github.com/philipwalton/flexbugs#9-some-html-elements-cant-be-flex-containers).
usageAlert1: When using the grid system with IE11 you will need to set an explicit `height` as `min-height` will not suffice and cause undesired results.

usage.desc: The Vuetify grid is heavily inspired by the [Bootstrap grid](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/layout/grid/). It is integrated by using a series of containers, rows, and columns to layout and align content. **If you are new to flexbox**, [Read the CSS Tricks flexbox guide](https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/a-guide-to-flexbox/#flexbox-background) for background, terminology, guidelines, and code snippets.

playground.heading: ### Layout playground
playground.desc: Test the layout props in a simple playground.

auto.heading: ### Auto sizing columns
auto.desc: Columns will automatically take up an equal amount of space within their parent container. This can be modified using the **cols** prop. You can also utilize the **sm**, **md**, **lg**, and **xl** props to further define how the column will be sized in different viewport sizes.

equal.heading: ### Equal width columns
equal.desc: You can break equal width columns into multiple lines. While there are workarounds for older browser versions, there was a [Safari flexbox bug](https://github.com/philipwalton/flexbugs#11-min-and-max-size-declarations-are-ignored-when-wrapping-flex-items). This shouldn't be necessary if you're up-to-date.

one-column-width.heading: ### One column width
one-column-width.desc: When using the auto-layout, you can define the width of only one column and still have its siblings to automatically resize around it.

variable-content.heading: ### Variable content width
variable-content.desc: Assigning breakpoint width for columns can be configured to resize based upon the nature width of their content.

grow-shrink.heading: ### Grow and Shrink
grow-shrink.desc: By default, flex components will automatically fill the available space in a row or column. They will also shrink relative to the rest of the flex items in the flex container when a specific size is not designated. You can define the column width of the `v-col` by using the **cols** prop and providing a value from **1 to 12**.

row-column-breakpoint.heading: ### Row and column breakpoints
row-column-breakpoint.desc: Dynamically change your layout based upon resolution. **(resize your screen and watch the top `row` layout change on sm, md, and lg breakpoints)**

vertical-alignment.heading: ### Vertical alignment
vertical-alignment.desc: Change the vertical alignment of flex items and their parents using the **align** and **align-self** properties.

horizontal-alignment.heading: ### Horizontal alignment
horizontal-alignment.desc: Change the horizontal alignment of flex items and their parents using the **justify** and **justify-self** properties.

no-gutters.heading: ### No gutters
no-gutters.desc: You can remove the negative margins from `v-row` and the padding from its direct `v-col` children using the **no-gutters** property.

wrapping.heading: ### Column wrapping
wrapping.desc: When more than 12 columns are placed within a given row (that is not using the `.flex-nowrap` utility class), each group of extra columns will wrap onto a new line.

order.heading: ### Order classes
order.desc: You can control the ordering of grid items. As with offsets, you can set different orders for different sizes. Design specialized screen layouts that accommodate to any application.

order-first-last.heading: ### Order last / first
order-first-last.desc: You can also designate explicitly **first** or **last** which will assign **-1** or **13** values respectively to the `order` CSS property.

offset.heading: ### Offset
offset.desc: Offsets are useful for compensating for elements that may not be visible yet, or to control the position of content. Just as with breakpoints, you can set an offset for any available sizes. This allows you to fine tune your application layout precisely to your needs.

offset-breakpoint.heading: ### Offset breakpoint
offset-breakpoint.desc: Offset can also be applied on a per breakpoint basis.

margin.heading: ### Margin utilities
margin.desc: Using the [auto margin helper utilities](/styles/flex#auto-margins) you can force sibling columns away from each other.

nested-grid.heading: ### Nested grid
nested-grid.desc: Grids can be nested, similar to other frameworks, in order to achieve very custom layouts.

unique-layouts.heading: ### Unique layouts
unique-layouts.desc: The power and flexibility of the Vuetify grid system allows you to create amazing user interfaces.

spacer.heading: ### Spacers
spacer.desc: The `v-spacer` component is useful when you want to fill available space or make space between two components.

tags.heading: ### Html tags
tags.desc: Sometimes you will want to specify a layout item as a specific tag, such as a `section` or `li` element.

v-col.alignSelf: Applies the [align-items](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/align-items) css property. Available options are **start**, **center**, **end**, **auto**, **baseline** and **stretch**.
v-col.cols: Sets the default number of columns the component extends. Available options are **1 -> 12** and **auto**.
v-col.sm: Changes the number of columns on small and greater breakpoints.
v-col.md: Changes the number of columns on medium and greater breakpoints.
v-col.lg: Changes the number of columns on large and greater breakpoints.
v-col.xl: Changes the number of columns on extra large and greater breakpoints.
v-col.offset: Sets the default offset for the column.
v-col.offsetSm: Changes the offset of the component on small and greater breakpoints.
v-col.offsetMd: Changes the offset of the component on medium and greater breakpoints.
v-col.offsetLg: Changes the offset of the component on large and greater breakpoints.
v-col.offsetXl: Changes the offset of the component on extra large and greater breakpoints.
v-col.order: Sets the default [order](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/order) for the column.
v-col.orderSm: Changes the order of the component on small and greater breakpoints.
v-col.orderMd: Changes the order of the component on medium and greater breakpoints.
v-col.orderLg: Changes the order of the component on large and greater breakpoints.
v-col.orderXl: Changes the order of the component on extra large and greater breakpoints.

v-row.align: Applies the [align-items](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/align-items) css property. Available options are **start**, **center**, **end**, **baseline** and **stretch**.
v-row.alignSm: Changes the **align-items** property on small and greater breakpoints.
v-row.alignMd: Changes the **align-items** property on medium and greater breakpoints.
v-row.alignLg: Changes the **align-items** property on large and greater breakpoints.
v-row.alignXl: Changes the **align-items** property on extra large and greater breakpoints.
v-row.alignContent: Applies the [align-content](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/align-content) css property. Available options are **start**, **center**, **end**, **space-between**, **space-around** and **stretch**.
v-row.alignContentSm: Changes the **align-content** property on small and greater breakpoints.
v-row.alignContentMd: Changes the **align-content** property on medium and greater breakpoints.
v-row.alignContentLg: Changes the **align-content** property on large and greater breakpoints.
v-row.alignContentXl: Changes the **align-content** property on extra large and greater breakpoints.
v-row.justify: Applies the [justify-content](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/justify-content) css property. Available options are **start**, **center**, **end**, **space-between** and **space-around**.
v-row.justifySm: Changes the **justify-content** property on small and greater breakpoints.
v-row.justifyMd: Changes the **justify-content** property on medium and greater breakpoints.
v-row.justifyLg: Changes the **justify-content** property on large and greater breakpoints.
v-row.justifyXl: Changes the **justify-content** property on extra large and greater breakpoints.
